context.speaker: Charles Rembar
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, that would constitute that kind of value.

context.speaker: Charles Rembar
context.text: But if I may return to your question --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Rembar, I'd just like to get this clear now.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This follows up with Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Are you urging on us that we set that where there is testimony directed to the issue of redeeming social value and that is credible testimony of acknowledged experts in the field that that ends any obscenity case without ever reading the material involved.

context.speaker: Charles Rembar
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Suppose --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I think that's easier, but don't quite see what other benefits --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Suppose it was profit sharing and the company's plan provided that an employee even though he's on a leave for the whole year of part of the year is entitled to share pro rata and the distribution of profits according to the whenever a formulas provided.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I suppose Mr. Justice Brennan's question would present the issue of whether a returning veteran would then claim that distribution of his few share of the profits?

context.speaker: Richard A. Posner
context.text: Well, I think he would, again the example -- it strikes me as unlikely that the employer would make this kind of provision for employees who weren't actually rendering service.

context.speaker: Richard A. Posner
context.text: But if the employer decides that furloughed employees are entitled to a continuing share in the profits, it seems entirely fair and inconsonance with the benevolent purposes of this legislation that a person involuntarily furlough because he was called into armed forces should be entitled to the same profit sharing or other benefits as a man, an employee, who likewise is not actually rendering service because he's on furlough.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: I was using garbage as a -- a generic term to things that have no use.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: To the extent, Mr. Justice Douglas, that you assume that everything is useful, then the issue in this case doesn't arise, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals assumed that the product of the this process was in fact useless and held that nevertheless the process to produce the product was a patentable useful process.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Now, this apparently is true in, for example, the industry in which this case arises, the drug industry and chemical industry, compounds that produce constantly, which have no known utility and lots of them never have any utility.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But last time, as Mr. Justice Douglas just pointed out, eventually do.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: That's true.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We've all read about the days when they used to dump gasoline -- as a -- as a waste byproduct when they were making the kerosene --

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: They'll be used as a way of stopping their competitors from engaging in competition with them with these processes, because the in -- the competitors may very well find a use.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: If you give Manson -- if you gave Manson, give a patent in this case on the process which was useless, Rosenkranz and Ringold who later find the use won't be able to use their useful process when they know the use for it without the permission of the prior patentee.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: He can use that patent to block off their attempts to give society something useful.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It seems to me, Mr. Bender that this policy argument that you're now making, and I understand that's what it is, was implicitly answered in Mr. Justice Harlan's question to you a moment ago, and that is if a process which does not produce a useful product is not patentable as you maintain, then all the incentive will be to -- instead of applying for a patent to keep the whole process secret and that would inhibit I should think further research by others, competitive research by others to find out if the -- if the end product is useful.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: That's a possibility, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: We don't dispute that.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Which, that one?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I thought you did.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: I don't understand which --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: If you win the co-pending patent case automatically in Justice Brennan's example, neither one of them can get a patent.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, on the hypothetical example.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Oh no!

context.speaker: William B. Devaney
context.text: Now on everything else we say he has the -- he has a positive and absolute duty to bargain with the union.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So –

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: At least it only goes with the settlement of the strike.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: As Justice White suggests you wouldn't bargain on wages and hourly rates which is originally involved in the replacements that because of the emergency conditions you say, you have to have some flexible -- flexible in anyway --

context.speaker: William B. Devaney

context.speaker: William B. Devaney
context.text: In the first place, I think that it is perfectly correct as has been suggested that the union who calls a strike is not going to agree to a weight for us to beat the strike.

context.speaker: William B. Devaney
context.text: But if they did how long, how long would it take?

context.speaker: William B. Devaney
context.text: The 1959 rules dispute which was before this Court in the P&O case started in 1959 and the decision of this Court wasn't until 1963.

context.speaker: William B. Devaney
context.text: So if it's a year -- if we -- if we exceed all speed records for having a dispute under the -- the Railway Labor Act it's perfectly obvious that you could not bargain, and you could not negotiate, and could not complete the procedures of the Act in order to -- to resume the operation of railroad for an indefinite period of time in the future.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well [Inaudible] as Justice White suggests that of course you recognized that you need to continue bargaining with the union, but that it's limited to the issues involved in the strike and in settlement and certainly does not include any [Inaudible] workout arrangements that maybe involved with the replacements.

context.speaker: William B. Devaney

context.text: Now, how about the -- how about grievances?

context.speaker: Carl Rachlin
context.text: That's true.

context.speaker: Carl Rachlin
context.text: Maybe it's a -- I trust it's not a perfect commentary on life in Clinton and I'm sure Mr. Kilbourne could indicate that there are many more people who use the library more often than twice.

context.speaker: Carl Rachlin
context.text: I would think that to me, sir, the nub of the case is the right not to have to explain yourself when you're behaving yourself properly in a public place.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I -- I -- I thought you said that you did not contest that finding. Do you -- do you agree that the evidence shows that -- and I quote “That they had a specific motive and a specific intent” and that was as shown beyond any reasonable doubt to refuse to leave the library even after they had been served and after they had been requested three times.

context.speaker: Carl Rachlin
context.text: I would be prepared --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Is there anything in the record to the effect that a Negro who wants to get a book from the red bookmobile can't do something?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: There is a testimony of some woman that used to work with the library I've forgotten her name, to the precise officer.

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: Well I -- I do not believe that that would be --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I think that -- I think Justice Fortas is referring to the testimony of Mrs. Laura Spears on page 136, 137 of the record.

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: I believe –

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: I didn't quite understand all your questions.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Was there any evidence in this record, did they offer any evidence or is there any evidence that there has ever been any person refused service in this library who has the books, any question, White or Black?

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Is there any record about the availability of this service other than this testimony that -- that Justice Douglas read it on the page 136 and 137, Mrs. Spears that you had this double system, one for Negroes and one for -- one for Whites.

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: Well I don't think there's any -- any other testimony to that effect.

context.speaker: Richard Kilbourne
context.text: It was I think -- if I remember the record will show you the number of questions along those lines that was objected to and the objection was sustained.

context.speaker: Paul O'Dwyer
context.text: It is our suggestion here that Puerto Ricans in the sense are a race and a race that are here in the sense that they have a language.

context.speaker: Paul O'Dwyer
context.text: They have a common tradition.

context.speaker: Paul O'Dwyer
context.text: They have a common purpose for over 300 years in their island home and it is our suggestion here that when any law, even though it may not have interfered with them at the time of its enactment, if later, it did actually interfere with their rights under the Fifteenth Amendment, that it should be stricken down.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Now, let's get back to the questions that Justice Stewart asked a while ago.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: You would say they can't do that with reference to any people from many countries?

context.speaker: Paul O'Dwyer
context.text: Any country -- American citizens in any country, I would -- well, I'm not prepared to argue that.

context.text: Now --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, is it -- to narrow this, Mr. Dunne, not having the supplemental agreements proved the condition upon which the exemption comes into play was not met and therefore, you're free if you can make out an antitrust law case, bring an antitrust action.

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: It's exactly our position, Your Honor, exactly our position.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, if an agreement is made between two foreign carries or two carriers in foreign commerce on rates, setting rates in so many dollars and cents, and that agreement is filed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, the Commission can either approve the agreement or not and one of the considerations, as Mr. Justice Douglas indicated, is that they might disapprove the agreement because the rates are so high or so low as to be detrimental to commerce of the United States.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, that's a different question than the reasonableness of the rates, isn't it?

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: That is a different question, yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I just wonder, who could have made these admissions on behalf of Holland?

context.speaker: Joseph E. Casey
context.text: I don't think that was an admission.

context.speaker: Joseph E. Casey
context.text: I think that that comes from the Federal Trade Commission attorneys.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, if this is -- as Justice Clark has referred to you, Holland Furnace Company admits the violation.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Who could have made that on behalf of Holland?

context.speaker: Joseph E. Casey
context.text: Well, I have no idea who made those in behalf of Holland?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: This question indeed was before the Court in 1961 in Lott against United States and the Court didn't decide it there but noticed the question, noticed some difficulty in it, and suggested that the question should be resolved not judicially but in the course of judicial decision but by the rule-making process.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: That's precisely what has been done.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: It has been resolved by the rule-making process consistently with the position which five of the six Courts of Appeals have taken under the 1946 Rule that is an untimely motion has no effect.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Do you think this failure to treat this is as a notice of appeal would be a denial of equal protection under Justice Black's opinion in the Griffin case?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: I don't see why.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Government has no right to equal protection, I would think.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But what I would have supposed under your position, all of the glosses used would be determined in the review proceeding.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I gather that hypothetically that your position is that the shipper would have in the first instance to initiate a review proceeding is that right?

context.speaker: J. Alton Boyer
context.text: If the shipper was seeking additional reparations.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The shipper has a reparation to it and it hasn't been -- the reparations have not been paid, now if I understood what you have just said to Justice Fortas, it is that in that instance, the shipper is not paid.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He cannot go into a District Court proceeding but has to initiate a review proceeding, did I correctly understand?

context.speaker: J. Alton Boyer
context.text: I don't think I've made myself clear sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: No, it's dated September 21st same way.

context.speaker: Charles V. Bell
context.text: The bottom half and --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Yes, right down at the bottom to the right.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Fortas points out; it's stated October 7th, 1959.

context.speaker: Charles V. Bell
context.text: Yes, October 7th, 1959.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And that was filled in this -- and this -- and this bottom half was filled in after a preliminary hearing, is that it?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I thought then Mr. -- that the [Inaudible] said this was a not charitable premise.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: That under -- it did not – the superior court said that under Georgia law that [Inaudible] couldn't be applied, there's no general charitable purpose expressed in the will.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: Yes, the Georgia courts rejected a claim about the cy pres doctrine and we don't press that in terms of that particular doctrine of trust law.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, that does bear I should think under colloquy of Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: If that's state law, and this can't be satisfied, well, then does that or doesn't it mean that the property has to go back to the heirs.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: I don't believe that immediately property can go back to the heirs.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: That that determination comes first and decides whether the Fourteenth Amendment command is applicable.
[Inaudible]

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: Considerations which lead to that result, it seems to me are in large part determined by the class of beneficiaries, the size of the class of beneficiaries, the nature of the facility involved, the impact of the discrimination, and --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Claiborne, I gather then anything is -- would be public and your definition if -- if it's open to everybody in the community except one defined class, say Negroes even though that the city or the governmental authorities have no ownership to control, as Mr. Justice Stewart posed the private park, run by private trustees.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I suppose that would go for any other facility wouldn't it that -- that was run by a private organization like the business organization?

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: No, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: The question I think is only whether or not we should have alleged with greater particularity when we did the rights which we now seek to assert because --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: How could you before the statute was passed?

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: That is exactly our position.We think that as far as --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, I think Mr. Justice Fortas' -- the basis of his question too?

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: I think that's right.

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: I think that --

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: We think that at that point, a federal court which has the case is called upon just as this Court called on all state courts which had such cases in Hamm and Lupper to look at the case before it and decide whether or not the case is indeed a punishment, harassment, etcetera.

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: If it is, we believe that that in itself falls into effect the removal statute which is intended to give federal jurisdiction to decide just such a question.

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: Now we do not for that purpose have to rely on the principle that the arrest were illegal at the time made although if necessary, we adhere to arguments previously made in this Court prior to Hamm and Lupper which we think the Court need not made -- need not reach that the constitution protected the conduct alleged in this case whether -- well, as the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I think we got started on this because in response to Mr. Justice Harlan's question, I think it was some time ago, you said you're not relying on the -- this as a constitutionally protected right for purposes of this case.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: So, we start looking for some other source of the right.

context.speaker: Anthony G. Amsterdam
context.text: If there is indeed -- if the Court should come to the conclusion that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not bar the prosecution as in this case or is not invocable as a basis of federal jurisdiction then we indeed have a question here that we have in the Peacock case.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: That would be --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you suggest that that is the test?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: What?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Justice Harlan (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: No, we have -- we don't have a state case here and we take no position on whether the scope of review in state cases should be different from your --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: We feel in this case that the deference to lower court findings if the Court wishes to review the cases like this in that manner is especially appropriate with regard to Liaison.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: With regard to the Housewife's Handbook and EROS, we recognized that at the trial there was substantial testimony that the works did not appeal to prurient interest, was not patently offensive in light of contemporary community standards and that they had redeeming value.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: And the Court may feel that in that circumstance where the judge rejects an overwhelming volume of testimony to that effect, his findings are not entitled to this much presumptive validity as in the case of Liaison where there's almost no testimony dealing with the value of the work or suggesting that the work is not --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, Mr. Bender, in line with Justice Fortas' question, the Government has the burden of proving obscenity beyond a reasonable doubt (Inaudible)?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is that the part of something more than just the introduction of evidence in the material?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: I think not.

context.text: It is counsel that is the vehicle for protection of all of the other rights.

context.speaker: William A. Norris
context.text: I was interested that the American Civil Liberties Union argued this primarily as a Fifth Amendment case on the ground that there may be some other ways of protecting their right to remain silent, but when it was all said and done, they agreed that the only one they could really think of was the Right to Counsel.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now can't the Escobedo case on analysis be explained in precisely the terms that Mr. Justice Black is suggesting.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: After all Escobedo had a lawyer, Danny Escobedo had a lawyer.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: He had a lawyer's advice and the lawyer had advised him not to talk and the very fact that Escobedo then did talk after he was confined within the police station, it was a very clear evidence that he'd been compelled to talk, isn't that right because he had been advised by a lawyer not to --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I was merely trying to suggest that the Escobedo decision can be explained in terms of the compulsion of a compelled confession particularly in view of the fact that -- and because of the fact that he did have a lawyer who had advised him not to talk.

context.speaker: William A. Norris
context.text: I suppose Mr. Justice Stewart it could be read that way but I prefer to read it the way the California Supreme Court had.

context.speaker: William A. Norris
context.text: I might say that --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Mr. Norris, excuse me again but as Justice Stewart said you did not espouse a totality of circumstances rule.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I'm not quite clear yet as to what the -- what you consider to be the right rule?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Whether you do or do not regard a totality of circumstances rule as appropriate.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Beside -- beside excuse me.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I beg your pardon --

context.speaker: William A. Norris
context.text: Yes sir, excuse me.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well are you answering Mr. Justice Fortas' question?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt you.

context.speaker: William A. Norris
context.text: I just wanted to say that it would be easier to – simpler to draw the line at one of these cut-off points but I don't think it would be meaningful because you would so easily permit the police to circumvent all of the safeguards of our society.

context.speaker: Richard A. Michael
context.text: He -- he is institutionalized until he either regain insanity.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But he regained insanity then he can be tried.

context.speaker: Richard A. Michael

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Richard A. Michael

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Alan B. Handler

context.speaker: Alan B. Handler

context.speaker: Alan B. Handler
context.text: That is --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The one he said?

context.text: We don't feel that every aid that a defendant or suspect is required to give the prosecution amounts to a privilege against self-incrimination.

context.text: Well, I just -- I just noticed when you answered --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- Justice Black earlier, that there's a compulsion again in giving evidence, of course the privilege was phrased “to be a witness against himself.”

context.speaker: Edward L. Davenport
context.text: That is --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I gather your argument is that the privilege then is limited to testimonial --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You don't have to go that far I gather for your purposes in this case, do you?

context.speaker: Albert J. Krieger
context.text: For my purposes in this case, I don't have to go that far.

context.speaker: Albert J. Krieger
context.text: I think that I am faced with a specific situation here which perhaps may well be unique.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well -- are you -- do you intend to comment on the power of this Court to exercise the case as I recall it with Mr. Justice Clark about the Yates wasn't it, to reduce these sentences.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: This is from the Court of Appeals' opinion.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: But if the verification provision of the Rule is to have any real meaning, it requires that a plaintiff must have knowledge of his own position and relationship to the suit, of the official identity of the parties against whom suit is brought.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And in this is what I want to ask you about, And that the plaintiff must have a general knowledge of the wrongful acts which he alleges as a foundation for his complaint.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And where a plaintiff makes an allegation on information -- makes clarification on information and belief that the plaintiff must have general knowledge of wrongful acts which she alleges as a foundation for the complaint.

context.speaker: William J. Condon

context.speaker: William J. Condon
context.text: He said there is a conflict because he did say --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I can understand your argument on the so called preemption side, but I don't see on the conflict side that whether you can create a conflict if you can get out of business.

context.speaker: William J. Condon

context.speaker: William J. Condon

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: I've -- excuse, yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I know that the Court of Appeals -- I wouldn't make it difficult (Inaudible) let's say the practice of the Court of Appeals that here they affirmed on the opinions both of Justice Stevens and the concurring opinion of Justice Rabin.

context.text: So I gather when Justice Rabin say this, "The difficulty with the provision of the defendant's Time, that if for trade, the previous dealing in the high (Inaudible) manner have represented that the play was a true version of that event.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: This was the hoax.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: They were using them as props for the purpose of making the article more readable and for selling more magazines.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: Now let me say, if they stated the truth about these people, that would have been perfectly within their constitutional rights but when -- what they did was to use them in a fictionalized context for the purposes of trade then certainly this does not present a constitutional problem.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: You had answered Mr. Justice Stewart's question earlier in the affirmative that is to say if newspaper just set out, wrote a story based upon some photographs taken of the intimacies of a married couple, published those as a news story since that's not fictionalized in the usual sense, you would say then that that were held to be an invasion of privacy under the New York statute this Court should find that the New York statute was applied in violation of the First Amendment, is that your position?

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: I would say that based on all of the New York cases and obviously, I must limit my answer to those cases over a period of 60 years that all of the New York cases have held that the element of fictionalization must be present in order to have a violation under the statute --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: That would be my answer to the question.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Our problem is to get at the theory of this --

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And so that you would say that Mr. Justice Stewart's example if I understand the last part of your statement just now that that could not constitutionally be held to invade the “right of privacy”.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: That would be my conclusion.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I am certain that --

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon

context.text: Well, I --

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: Therefore, a chilling effect, I think, could be seen then.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: I think that distinguishes this case.

context.speaker: Richard M. Nixon
context.text: Thank you.

context.text: The critical factor is the effect of the ruling.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: On the other hand, the justices of this Court came to the diverging conclusion with respect to the type of ruling which would have the requisite effect.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Justices Brennan and Justice Whitaker expressed the view that a judgment which will end of course an escapade of the defendant was sufficient to make it a motion in bar.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That's --

context.speaker: Ralph S. Spritzer
context.text: And we say there is a sound and a fair explanation of the decision to reindict the defendants here in the manner that was done and one which has not been shown to work any specific prejudice in terms of their ability to defend against the charge.

context.text: There are a couple of dealers in this case that had some trouble ultimately getting paid, but that was the normal practice.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: The discount house would pay for the car at the time the discount house received it from the dealer, and the arrangement was ordinarily that the dealer would sell to the discount house at a certain stipulated mark-up over the dealer's invoice.

context.text: Now, there is Mr. Justice another type of arrangement, not just this one.

context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: The title passed from the dealer to the costumer, but the mechanics of paying it where that the costumer paid the discount house which in turns paid the dealer.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Now, the rights here involved are spelled out in the indictment and they fall into three main categories, first, rights grounded in the Equal Protection Clause, specifically the right to the equal utilization without discrimination upon the basis of race of all public utilities owned, operated or managed by the state including the streets and highways et cetera.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Secondly, the right to travel freely to and from any state and the right to use its instrumentalities of interstate commerce, three, the right to equal advantages of restaurants, motion picture theaters and other privately owned places of public accommodation guaranteed by Title II of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The right to the nondiscriminatory use of public facilities owned or operated by the state itself is one grounded in the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And again in the light of, I have here United States v. Williams but I should add, in the light of the opinion of Mr. Justice Douglas in United States versus Williams, the threshold question with respect to this branch of the case is whether Section 241 protects Fourteenth Amendment rights at all.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The District Judge said no.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: For an affirmative answer on the issue we rely upon the brief in the case we've just argued, but in addition we say, “Following the legislative history, we show and operate that Section 241 was meant to reach private individuals acting in conspiracy and once you apply the strict requirements of the Screws case we urged that so construed the statute is not impermissibly vague.”

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We think it as one of the [Inaudible] ones.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: When a group of private citizens get together and say “Look, we are going to plan all of these out for the purpose we're just sick and tired of what's going on and we're going to do it and somebody would suggest to bomb a church like they did in Birmingham, somebody say “Do this like they did in this, why not do that” and the question is whether or not they don't have to do all of these things to come under it, but where they have all of these charged, I think we intend to rely on, and I don't see the great magnitude that comes out of the state officers of being involved, I just never had.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But this is a conspiracy of private individuals.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: No I'm -- you said that -- as I understood you that they acted a lot of vagueness or commit this -- again the combination of schools and Mr. Justice Douglas opinion of William.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And the way that this conspiracy charges worded here it's --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, what I wanted to get is--

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I thought the whole business to avoid for vagueness that goes to the point where there -- one has adequate, know this before he commits certain conduct but that conduct does -- made a crime under certain law.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Would this sort of things under some of the older cases have led one to think before he committed it that he had committed a federal crime under 241.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: My position is that even if it would fall afoul of the language in Cruikshank et cetera, it is definitely within the specific the language in Screws as interpreted by the four judges and Mr. Justice Douglas opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: They said that conspiracy puts the necessary intent.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Do you remember the troubles Mr. Solicitor General we had with the Wilcox and [Inaudible] you know that so to speak, and the problems we had in James case?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes sir but to pick (Voice Overlap)

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: [Inaudible]

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Fortas.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: This en bancment in the Guest case does not -- does it specifically refer to the Fourteenth Amendment, so many words, does it?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: No, it says equal protection.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Only a direct federal right.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We have it starting on page 57.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, do I understand then Mr. Solicitor General what you're suggesting in answer to Mr. Justice Fortas' at all events without reference to the Fourteenth Amendment, this indictment can be sustained on the allegations that did utter was the right to travel freely, that's the Crandall and Nevada created federal rights, is that it?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I take the position --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And there is no question that the rights here are asserted are rights protected by the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the briefs we spell out all of the areas on page 11 of our brief.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I mentioned before this right is grounded in the Equal Protection Clause but the District Court held that Section 241 did not encompass Fourteenth Amendment Rights at all.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: So once again, we come back to Mr. Justice Douglas' opinion in the Williams Case which recognized the specific rights secured by the Fourteenth and mid -- Fifteenth Amendments as being rights within the scope for Section 241.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: With that in mind, we have argued in the Price Case due process rights were also included.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: No one has suggested a satisfactory basis for excluding Equal Protection Rights while still keeping due process rights, either should be a right of privilege secured by the Constitution which is using the like of Section 241.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Although, we may well wish to argue upon a later occasion that the federal government may protect men against private violence aimed at suppressing speech, association or political activity for present purposes, we may assume that even in such a case the federal government could not constitutionally interfere if the state were supplying equal protection.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In such case, there's no relationship between the state and the victims beyond the obligation to provide them with the same protection as other citizens.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Well, general, excuse me a bit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes Mr. Justice Fortas?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It seems to me in your argument that you are ignoring paragraph 4 in the indictment and with it – and I wonder if you're doing that deliberately that is to say very, very poorly indictment excuses the defendants were conspiracy to deprive these persons of the right to travel to and from the state of Georgia and the use of highway facilities and other instrumentalities of interstate commerce.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And I think I've asked something along these lines before but your argument bewilders me is respect that I don't know just where in your scheme of reasoning about the statute that particular paragraph fits.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We take the position that they are federal rights for the reason that the access to them, the state having given the Negroes access to these rights under the Fourteenth Amendment then they are protected by the federal government.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: They are not state's rights.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I suppose the state might respond that the state has given these people access to the streets and public facilities and so on, on the basis of the state's own constitution.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, of course, Mr. Justice Fortas, the problem is the state is not in this case by any stretch of imagination.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I know.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I'm just trying to get your argument whether the state is here or not.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: And the due process right.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Yes, that's all.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That's an order for it to be a due process in order for it to fulfill the due process requirements, it has to do that.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And in the Williams case, the opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas that pointed out the 241 meets the first requirement by virtue of being a conspiracy statute.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The provision does not punish merely because someone was causing or permitting in an injurious result by negligence or otherwise, but only -- you get conspiracy only if there's a purposeful agreement to inflict the injury.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Vagueness is not imparted because the statute reaches private conspiracies else it could never serve its most traditional function as for example, the Wardell case and the Logan Case.

context.text: And two, it is further alleged that they use their official powers to release state prisoners, turn them over to a lynch mob which was shielded by the presence of another state officer, so that they could be summarily punished without benefit of trial.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This, to my mind puts this case warily within the rule announced in the Screws case, and indeed within the rule announced in the Williams case at least insofar as Mr. Justice Douglas' opinion was concerned.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the Screws case, there was no problem with the indictment, no court found any problem with indictment in that case.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And in the Williams case, if you read the indictment, the indictment was closely similar to the one here.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This last statement from Senator Pool's speech, emphasizing his concern with unofficial action, particularly conspiracies like the plan which he explicitly mentions, suggests the only argument against reading Section 41 to reach Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment rights.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: It has been said that because this statute, unlike 242, is not confined to acts done under color of law to officials.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: It cannot have been meant to protect Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment rights, which can only be invaded by state officers or at least by persons acting color -- under color of state law.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
